thread.section_title: Australian Business & World Finance News - Yahoo!7 Finance
thread.title: $A falls on Chinese market concerns

title: $A falls on Chinese market concerns
text:
Thu, Aug 20, 2015, 5:58 PM AEST - Australia Markets closed $A falls on Chinese market concerns AAP – 21 minutes ago Print 
A third straight day of sharp falls on China's share market has sent the Australian dollar lower. 
At 1700 AEST on Thursday the currency was trading at 73.13 US cents, down from 73.53 cents on Wednesday. 
The fall came late in the day, as the Shanghai Composite index fell more than three per cent in afternoon trade. 
The Australian dollar's performance has been closely tied to movements on China's turbulent market for the past couple of days, Western Union Business Solutions currency strategist Steven Dooley said. 
Traders would have brushed off moves in China's equity market in the past, but it is increasingly having a larger impact on risk sentiment in global markets, he said. 
"Previously it was treated as a casino and ignored - people still treat it as a casino but now we're actually paying attention," he said. 
"The Chinese economy is clearly slowing rapidly. There is a real risk of a hard landing and that's what the stock market is reflecting." 
At 1700 AEST, the Australian dollar was at 90.69 Japanese yen, down from Wednesday's close of 91.37 yen, and at 65.68 euro cents, down from 66.45 euro cents. 
The bond market firmed as US Federal Open Market Committee minutes raised concerns about the likelihood of an interest rate hike next month. 
"It signalled that September is not a done deal," St George senior economist Janu Chan said. 
"They're highlighting that they want more information and confidence that inflation is going to move back to their target and the economy is improving enough." 
At 1630 AEST, the September 2015 10-year bond futures contract was trading at 97.300 (implying a yield of 2.700 per cent), up from 97.225 (2.775 per cent) on Wednesday. 
The September 2015 three-year bond futures contract was at 98.110 (1.890 per cent), up from 98.060 (1.940 per cent). @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Greece makes ECB repayment AFP
